Graphical abstract The different loading sequence CeO2 and Pd over Al2O3 support influences palladium dispersion by the interaction, which is main factor in influencing the catalytic activity. Ce/Pd/Al catalyst owns smaller palladium particle size and higher palladium dispersion than Pd/Ce/Al catalyst, which is considered as active site. A simple process is described as is shown above, and specific process is illustrated in my article. The Pd-only close-coupled catalysts of the different loading sequence of CeO2 and Pd over Al2O3 were prepared using consecutive wetness impregnation method. Differences in structural, surface properties and catalytic performance, together with the thermal aging behaviors of catalyst at 1000 °C were investigated systematically by XRD, TPR, XPS, ICP, CO adsorption and TEM. Consequently, the Ce/Pd/Al catalysts loaded Ce after Pd over the alumina show superior structural properties before and after aging treatment, suggesting the Ce/Pd/Al catalysts possess better thermal resistance than Pd/Ce/Al catalysts loaded Pd after Ce. Moreover, the aged Ce/Pd/Al catalysts possess stronger reducible probed by TPR, and HRTEM and CO adsorption show smaller particles size of Pd and higher palladium dispersion. As a result, for Ce/Pd/Al catalysts, more palladium sites play a role as active site, which promotes low temperature conversion of pollutants effectively. The catalytic performance of the catalysts is forcefully subject to palladium dispersion and reduction property, especially for NO conversion, and the light-off temperature of NO over aged Ce/Pd/Al is 27 °C lower than aged Pd/Ce/Al. The results have demonstrated that novel loading sequence is beneficial to catalytic activity which is maintained even after aging treatment. Keywords Loading sequence Pd-only close-coupled catalysts Palladium dispersion Thermal stability Catalytic performance 1 Introduction With the wide usage of automobiles in recent years, emissions from gasoline engine-powered vehicles have been considered as one of the main source for air pollution [1–3]. The close-coupled catalyst (CCC), which is typically installed close to engine, is used to reduce the cold-tart emission. Hence, the CCC is usually employed during high temperature operation. Furthermore, Tightened standards for contaminants including unburned hydrocarbons (HCs), carbon monoxide (CO) and nitrogen oxide (nitric oxide and nitrogen dioxide) are being taken into account. Therefore, the low temperature catalytic activity and thermal stability are two great challenges [1,4]. Generally, catalytic converters are regarded as the most sufficient solution for emission reduction [5]. Known close-coupled catalyst generally comprises one or more platinum group metals, and normally located upon high surface area, refractory oxide support like gamma-Al2O3 (γ-Al2O3). Extensive investigations concerning Pd-only catalysts are made for its favorable performance in hydrocarbon oxidation [6–8]. It was reported that among Pd0, PdO and PdO2, PdO is considered as the most active species in the conversion of hydrocarbons [9,10]. However, it is hard to maintain PdO at such a high temperature (higher than 1000 °C) which close-coupled catalyst must be exposed to, and the decomposition of PdO into Pd0 at 750 °C could aggravate the agglomeration of Pd species. [11] As a result, the sintered bulk Pd0 is hard to be fully reoxidated during cooling process and leads to decrease effective content of PdO (so-called “dispersion”) [12]. To maintain more active sites over Pd/Al2O3 loaded Pd over alumina, additives are commonly adopted, such as ceria, zirconia, while the catalysts still keep lower palladium dispersion which the catalytic activity is sensitive to. According to relative literatures [13–15], ceria is an effective promoter in catalytic reaction for its oxygen storage capacity, and CeO2-based systems can promote PdO formation during cooling at higher temperature and stabilize PdO species effectively through an interaction via surface oxygen. In addition, ceria could suppress the agglomeration of palladium species by an intimate interaction and accelerate the reoxidation properties of Pd0 [12]. Nowadays, various addition manners of ceria and Pd has been explored, including co-impregnation [16], step-wise impregnation [17], combustion [18] and the like, and diverse addition ways lead to different the nature of precious metal supported on supports because of the interaction between Pd and ceria. Traditionally, for step-wise impregnation method, ceria is generally loaded over Al2O3, and then Pd is as the second layer [19,20], aiming at containing higher surface Pd concentration. It’s assumed that palladium species which are exposed on the surface of the catalyst would provide more active sites for catalytic reaction. Besides, the most of Pd would interact with ceria instead of Al2O3 under this loading sequence. Recently, many investigations carried out on the influence of the support concluded that catalytic properties and stability under reaction of Pd-based catalyst strongly depend on the nature of the support, and on the interaction that exists between the palladium particles and the support. In this work, in order to decrease the sintering of the palladium species and increase the palladium dispersion, ceria as the second loading layer named as Ce/Pd/Al catalyst was investigated systematically, can suppress the sintering of palladium species by the interaction which may be the formation of PdOCe bond [21] and occupy the different space site with palladium species over the alumina which is called diffusion barrier [15]. However, the reference sample is prepared by traditional loading order designed as Pd/Ce/Al catalyst. Astoundingly, we find that leaving ceria instead of Pd as the second layer is favorable for the catalytic performance, and is demonstrated to be a more excellent loading sequence than Pd instead of ceria as the second layer simultaneously. The effect of the loading sequence of Pd and ceria was investigated from textural, structural, morphological and reduction properties after aging. N2-adsoprtion, power X-ray diffraction (XRD) and high resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM) were carried out. Concurrently, elements composition and adsorption character were measured by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), inductively coupled plasma-atomic emission spectrometry (ICP-AES) and in situ diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform spectroscopy (DRIFTS). The stability of PdO and palladium dispersion were tested by H2 temperature programed reduction (H2-TPR) and CO adsorption method, respectively. 2 Experimental 2.1 Preparation of Pd/Ce/Al and Ce/Pd/Al catalysts All the catalysts were obtained by wetness impregnation method. Firstly, the Al2O3 powders (SBET = 111 m2 g−1, Paterson) were impregnated with the aqueous solution of Ce(NO3)3·6H2O (Keshi, 99 wt%). According to our previous work, the appropriate amount of CeO2 loading was chosen as 17.5 wt% (Fig. S1). Afterwards, the impregnated sample was dried at 100 °C and then calcined at 600 °C for 3 h. Secondly, aqueous Pd(NO3)2 solution (Heraeus, 15.50 wt% Pd) was impregnated onto the obtained supports, then, the impregnated powder was submitted to drying at 120 °C and calcining at 550 °C for 3 h. Finally, the catalyst powders are ball milled with a binder to form slurry and coated on a commercial monolithic cordierite (2.5 cm3, Corning, China) containing Pd 2 g L−1. The washcoat loading was obtained based on the difference in the weight of the monolith before washcoating and calcining, and the loading amounts for the catalysts were 120 g L−1. The monolithic catalyst was calcined at 550 °C for 3 h, and the obtained fresh catalyst was named as Pd/Ce/Al-f. After 1000 °C calcination in air for 5 h the aged catalyst was obtained, which is labeled as Pd/Ce/Al-a. The synthesis of Ce/Pd/Al was the same as the synthesis of Pd/Ce/Al stating above except for the sequence of the first step and the second step exchanged. The fresh catalyst was labeled as Ce/Pd/Al-f and the aged catalyst was named as Ce/Pd/Al-a. 2.2 Catalytic activity test The activities of these catalysts for eliminating target pollutants were tested in a multiple fixed-bed flow microreactor, and the gas mixture similar to gasoline engine exhaust was passed through the reactor continuously. The simulated exhaust gas contained a mixture gas of CO (0.6%), C3H8 (0.06%), NO (0.06%), CO2 (12%), H2O (10%), and N2 (balance) and O2 (adjustable). The gas hourly space velocity (GHSV) was 40,000 h−1. The concentration of C3H8, NO and CO was analyzed online by a five-component analyzer (FGA-4100, Foshan Analytical Instrument Co., Ltd., China) before and after the simulated gas was passed through the microreactor. The catalysts were pretreated under the reaction condition at 550 °C for 1 h prior to the measurement, and the catalytic performance was tested during temperature programmed cooling process. 2.3 Characterization techniques The textual properties were measured by N2 adsorption–desorption at −196 °C on Quantachrome automated surface area & pore size analyzer (Autosorb SI). The samples were degassed at 300 °C for 3 h under vacuum before measurement, and the specific surface areas of the samples were calculated by the Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) method. To investigate the phase changes occurred on samples, X-Ray Diffraction (XRD) of the catalysts were carried out on a Rigaku DX-2500 diffractometer equipped with Cu Kα (λ = 0.15406 nm) as radiation, the interval of the spectra was 0.03°. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) analysis results were recorded on a British Kratos XSAM-800 electron spectrometer equipped with Mg Kα (1253.6 eV) as the radiation. The XPS data associated with Pd 3d, Al 2p, O 1 s and Ce 3d core levels were collected for all samples. The binding energies of the elements were calibrated using the C 1 s peak at 284.6 eV as the internal standard reference. Elemental composition was determined by inductively coupled plasma-atomic emission spectrometry (ICP-AES) using a Varian 715-ES. Temperature Programmed Reduction (H2-TPR) was carried out on a self-assembled equipment. Before TPR measurement, the samples were dried at 120 °C to remove water. The reduction reaction was performed using a mixture of 5% H2/N2 (v/v) at a heating rate of 9 °C/min from RT to 600 °C. The up-take amounts of H2 were detected by TCD during this process. The microstructures of catalysts were observed by transmission electron microscopy equipped with field emission gun (FE-TEM) (JEM2100F, JEOL) at the accelerating voltage of 200 kV. TEM images were recorded by CCD camera. The elemental distribution of the samples was analyzed by the energy dispersive spectrometer (EDS) to show the element distribution at lower magnification. The CO-Pd adsorption method was performed to estimate the dispersion of palladium particles. Before the measurement, the samples were reduced at 450 °C for 40 min using 5% H2/N2 (v/v) at a heating rate of 10 °C/min from RT to 450 °C, and then using N2 at a decreasing rate of 10 °C/min from 450 °C to RT. Finally, the samples were carried out at RT using 2% CO/N2 for 30 min. DRIFTS spectra were collected using a Nicolet 6700 FTIR with a MCT detector. All spectra were obtained with a resolution of 4 cm−1 and an accumulation of 100 scans. The samples were in situ pretreated for 0.5 h in N2 (30 ml min−1) stream at 50 °C. Subsequently, the system was cooled down to 50 °C in N2 and the background spectra were recorded. Two types of DRIFTS experiments were performed: (1) CO adsorption experiments were performed at 30 °C with a flow of 0.75% CO/Ar. Prior to CO adsorption, the catalyst was first reduced by purified H2 at 350 °C for 0.5 h and then purged with Ar for 0.5 h. (2) DRIFTS reaction experiments corresponding to the simulated reaction mixture were conducted, and the spectra were recorded as a function of temperature. Except for water vapor, the gas concentration of the gas mixture was the same as those in the catalytic activity tests. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Textural properties The specific surface area, average pore size and total pore volume of the catalysts were measurement by N2 adsorption-desorption experiments at the temperature of the liquid nitrogen. The specific surface area and total pore volume were calculated according to the BET and BJH method, respectively, and the results, including surface area, pore volume and average pore radius, are demonstrated in Table 1 . As shown in Table 1, the surface area of fresh catalysts is larger than that of aged, indicating that a certain degree of sintering occurs obviously [19] during the aging treatment, leading to a conspicuous loss of specific surface. For fresh catalysts, Ce/Pd/Al-f shows higher specific area and lower pore diameter than that of Pd/Ce/Al-f, and it suggests that palladium species may occupy a part of pore volume of alumina and CeO2 over the surface of the catalyst could offer some specific area. However, barely no distinction of the specific areas is observed over the two aged catalysts while disparity of the catalytic performance still exists after thermal aging which will be discussed behind, implying that the specific area is not the critical factor in this system, which is advantageous to enhance the catalytic performance of the supported catalyst and the sintering degree of alumina is almost the same, as discussed in the following section. As is well known, aging treatment often results in the collapse of small pores and the formation of larger ones, leading to form a larger pore size [22], which can well accounts for the larger pore radius of the aged samples compared with the corresponding fresh ones. In summation, different loading sequence has not a conspicuous effect on the textural property of the catalysts. 3.2 XRD characterization The part results of XRD were summarized in Table 2 . Fig. 1 shows the XRD patterns of all catalysts, and CeO2 crystallite sizes and lattice parameters of fresh and aged catalysts are illustrated in Table 2. For fresh catalysts, the diffraction peaks at 28.6°, 33.1°, 47.5°, 56.3° and 76.7° are observed over both catalysts, which are assigned to the cubic fluoride CeO2 crystal phase [12]. The diffraction peaks of CeO2 over Pd/Ce/Al-f are obviously sharper than that of Ce/Pd/Al-f, implying that the crystallite size of CeO2 is larger by directly introducing ceria on the Al2O3 surface. The mean crystallite size of CeO2 calculated by the Scherrer equation confirms the statement (see in Table 2), and the crystallite sizes of CeO2 of Ce/Pd/Al and Pd/Ce/Al were 7.0 and 9.1 nm, respectively. Other than CeO2 species, there are diffraction peaks corresponding to Al2O3 which is located at 45.8° and 66.8°. However, no peaks correlated to PdO or Pd was observed, a possible reason is that Pd species are amorphous particles and well dispersed on the surface [23] or is incorporated into the CeO2 lattice [18], and furthermore, the grain might be too small to be observed by XRD which corresponds to the small Pd loadings [19,24]. To investigate the effect of the double thermal treatment and make the result convincing, the Ce/Pd/Al-f sample is calcined again at 550 °C labeled as Ce/Pd/Al-f-550 behind. The part results of XRD were summarized in Table S2, and Fig. S2 shows the XRD patterns of the both samples. Ce/Pd/Al-f-550 sample presents almost the same peak intensity and shape as Ce/Pd/Al-f sample. Meanwhile, as is shown in Table S2, the change of ceria particle size is signifcantly small before and after calcined at 550 °C again, whose particles size are obviously smaller than that of Pd/Ce/Al2O3-f, suggesting that Ce/Pd/Al-f sample reveals more preferable heat-resisting property and structural stability. The aforementioned observation further declares that the novel loading sequence processes more excellent thermal resistance. After aging treatment, all XRD profiles show a peak sharpening to a certain extent on account of the grain growth during the aging process. Meanwhile, Al2O3 usually transforms from gamma phase to theta, delta, or alpha phase after themral treatment at 1000 °C [25], and visible γ-Al2O3 phases can be observed for all samples, but peak intensity of alumina keeps the same and no obvious transformation of γ-Al2O3 to θ-Al2O3 or δ-Al2O3 is displayed after aging, suggesting that the heating-resisting property of Al2O3 is improved by the presence of cerium [15], thus Al2O3 crystallites may keep nearly amorphous structure [23] or gamma phase. However, an obvious peak at 34.0° is detected over both catalysts, which is ascribed to the diffraction peak of PdO (101) (110), suggesting that a severe agglomeration of Pd species occurs during aging process, and the tiny Pd particles in the fresh catalysts are apt to grow up upon thermal treatment, and subsequently lose atomic dispersion on the support. From Fig. 1, analysing the peak FWHM value of the two samples, we can obtain that the peak FWHM value of Ce/Pd/Al-a (circa 0.288°) is obviously larger than that of Pd/Ce/Al-a (circa 0.224°), declaring that the peak assigned to PdO species of Pd/Ce/Al-a becomes more sharpened than that of Ce/Pd/Al-a and the sintering of Pd/Ce/Al is more serious than Ce/Pd/Al during the aging process. I.e., Ce/Pd/Al catalyst possesses better structural stability than Pd/Ce/Al catalyst upon thermal aging. In addition, the phase of Pd0 is not detected, suggesting that a portion of the Pd0 formed during high temperature is reoxidized during cooling process [26] and another portion of Pd including metal palladium and palladium oxide can disperse on the support well in the form of amorphous particles. It is also worth noting that the crystallite size of the catalysts follows a sequence of Pd/Ce/Al > Ce/Pd/Al, irrespective of the fresh or thermal treated samples, declaring that ceria instead of Pd as the second layer has a positive influence on maintaining a comparatively small crystallite size, the grain growth upon with strong interaction between Pd and Al2O3 is retarded, and the particle aggregation can be effectively suppressed for Ce/Pd/Al-a. It is concluded again that Ce/Pd/Al possesses better structural stability than Pd/Ce/Al upon thermal aging. Moreover, after the aging, the lattice constants of Pd/Ce/Al-a was larger than that of Ce/Pd/Al-a, and the variation of lattice structure was induced by the loading of palladium component and calcination at high temperature, declaring that Ce/Pd/Al catalyst forms more oxygen vacancies during the thermal aging, which are in favor of catalytic activity. In other words, more palladium component might dissolve into the lattice of ceria for Pd/Ce/Al-a. The possible reason is that Pd instead of ceria as the second layer only forms interaction with ceria. 3.3 H2-TPR results The oxidation-reduction property of PdO x was characterized by H2-temperature programmed reduction technique, and the results were illustrated in Fig. 2 . According to relevant literatures [27,28], the low temperature peaks below 200 °C are ascribed to the reduction of PdO species, and the reducibility of palladium oxide is an important factor influencing the catalytic performance [29], especially under insufficient oxygen condition. As shown in Fig. 2(a), obvious differences among the both are found for fresh catalysts. Pd/Ce/Al-f and Ce/Pd/Al-f feature only one reduction peak, and the reduction temperature of Ce/Pd/Al-f is 17 °C higher than that of Pd/Ce/Al-f. Meanwhile, the hydrogen consumption in terms of the integral peak areas of Pd/Ce/Al-f is relatively larger than that of Ce/Pd/Al-f. From the above mentioned phenomenom, Pd/Ce/Al-f exhibits the excellent reducibility due to its lower reduction temperature and the hydrogen consumption, suggesting a favorable stability of PdO x exposed to outermost layer directly is achieved when ceria is loaded after Pd. In fact, in the complex catalytic reaction system, the redox properties of active palladium species are not the main factors in influencing catalytic performance, other factors such as Pd dispersion, configuration and morphology of active Pd sites, and the interaction between Pd and supports may play a more significant role [30]. The intensity of reduction peak decreases obviously owing to the lower dispersion of active PdO species caused by the serious sintering during the aging process. As we could see in Fig. 2(b), the reduction temperature of Pd/Ce/Al-a is 97 °C while Ce/Pd/Al-a possess two reduction temperatures at 93 °C and 115 °C respectively, suggesting that most of PdO x over Ce/Pd/Al-a is easier to be reduced than that of Pd/Ce/Al-a and a small portion of reduction peak is assigned to the occurrence of back-spillover poccess of oxygen from ceria to PdO [31,32]. In other words, a part of cerium oxide is reduced by H2 at lower temperature, and as is well known, reduction temperature of ceria is more than 500 °C under hydrogen atmosphere [19,33], suggesting that ceria of the catalysts loaded Ce after Pd can show more reducible than that of the catalysts loaded Pd after Ce and oxygen storage-release can proceed better at lower temperature, which may facilitate the conversion of CH and CO effectively. According to the literatures [19,20], the reduction temperature for PdO species of Ce/Pd/Al-a is lower than that of Pd/Ce/Al-a, since the hydrogen consumption in terms of the integral peak areas is almost the same for the aging samples, proving the result that the reduction performance of Ce/Pd/Al-a is relatively better than Pd/Ce/Al-a. The gap of reduction temperature is slightly smaller, declaring that the redox properties of active palladium species are not the main factors in influencing catalytic performance. After thermal aging, the reduction temperature of all catalysts shifts to lower temperature, which illustrates that the reduction ability of the catalyst is improved. There may be two reasons to explain this result. The first possible explanation is that the interaction between cerium species and PdO is enhanced by forming CeOPd bonds during thermal aging which can restrain the sintering of palladium species and makes the Ce/Pd/Al-a catalyst keep relatively higher palladium dispersion [21] than the catalyst no adopting any promoter, which is further verified by CO adsorption. There exists spillover phenomenon of adsorption hydrogen. Metal palladium can transfer adsorption hydrogen to ceria better under the hydrogen atmosphere, and ceria is easily reduced at lower temperature [28,30,34]. The second cause is the decomposition of PdO during thermal aging, leading to more metal palladium particles. Metal palladium can assist the dissociation and spillover of hydrogen, resulting in the decrease of reduction temperature [23]. 3.4 XPS results and ICP-AES The surface elemental composition and atomic ratio of the catalysts were analyzed by XPS. The surface elemental contents were calculated from Ce 3d, Al 2p, O 1s and Pd 3d core level spectra and the results are listed in Table 3 . The obtained XPS spectra of Pd 3d and Ce 3d are plotted in Fig. 3 . Eight peaks can be observed in the spectra of Ce 3d, those labeled “u” arise from 3d3/2, and the others marked as “v” are attributed to 3d5/2. The doublet (u’, v’) is characteristic of Ce3+, while the others are all assigned to the diversified states of Ce4+ [35]. For the supported Pd catalysts, the oxygen vacancies related to the Ce3+ species close to the noble metal particles are universally considered as active sites for NO reduction, and hence the higher proportion of Ce3+ can contribute to improved NO catalytic activity [36,37]. As shown in Table 4 , slight differences are observed between the theoretical amount of palladium (1.64 wt%), and the experiment dates are evaluated by mean of ICP-AES. Amounts of palladium vary then between 1.7 wt% and 1.4 wt%. Regardless of the fresh and aged catalysts, as Pd/Ce/Al catalyst possesses the larger proportion of Ce3+ in Ce, which does not accord with the XRD result obviously, the surface Ce3+ atomic content of Ce/Pd/Al catalyst is almost the same as that of Pd/Ce/Al catalyst from Table 4, suggesting that for Ce/Pd/Al catalyst more oxygen vacancies exist in the bulk phase and the surface oxygen vacancies may be not main factor in infulencing the catalytic performance. PdO particles are universally considered as the actve site of catalytic activity, while the Pd/Ce/Al catalyst possesses slightly higher surface PdO content than Ce/Pd/Al catalyst. As for this condition, we know that surface content of Pd species over Ce/Pd/Al is lower slightly and total content of Pd is almost the same obtained by ICP-AES. From Table 5 , the ratio of surface PdO content is larger than the amounts ratio of palladium species, and the aged catalysts are in possession of lower surface Pd content than the corresponding catalysts, suggesting that part of Pd is dispersed in the bulk phase of the catalyst after the aging treatment. Meanwhile, the lattice constant of Ce/Pd/Al is smaller than that of Pd/Ce/Al before and after the aging, which is not in accordance with the XPS result. It is generally accepted that the coexistence of Ce3+ and Ce4+ is indicative of oxygen vacancies, which is of great importance to the redox properties and the corresponding catalytic activity [38]. The cause for this discrepancy is that the result probed with XPS finds surface content of various elements on account of the finite electron mean free path [12], while the results detected by XRD and ICP reflect overall average condition. According to relevant works reported [13,14], CeO2-based systems can effectively stabilize PdO species through an interaction with surface oxygen. Concerning the fresh and aging Ce/Pd/Al catalyst, although its total surface content of palladium species is slightly lower than the corresponding Pd/Ce/Al catalyst, according to calculation its metal palladium content is higher than the Pd/Ce/Al obviously. XRD result declares that Pd/Ce/Al displays the worser thermal stability, which could be possible that Pd as second loading layer makes the surface possess higher content of precious metal, leading to the severer sintering of particles exposed at high temperature directly during aging process and the worser dispersion of noble metal. However, for Ce/Pd/Al catalyst, ceria as the second layer acts as diffsion barrizer [15] and can impede the direct contaction of palladium particles, implying that the sintering of palladium particles requires higher temperature. Hence, the truth that Pd/Ce/Al catalyst owning higher surface PdO content than Ce/Pd/Al catalyst is not in agreement with the catalytic activity can be explained by the dispersion of palladium species. The Ce/Pd/Al catalyst is in possession of the higher dispersion, leading to more active sites dispersed on the surface of the support and showing more promiment catalytic activity, which will be further confirmed by the HRTEM and CO adsorption. After the aging treatment, the catalysts own smaller surface palladium species and ceria, and there are two accounts to explain the change. The first cause may be the migration of atom at higher temperature, and the suface palladium species and ceria particles enter into the bulk phase and alumina migrates from the inner to the surface, which corresponds with the datas in Table 4, leading to the diminution of palladium species and cerium content and the increase of aluminum after aging [19,39]. The other account is the decomposition of PdO into metal palladium and the agglomeration of palladium species by the structural collapse of supports during the aging treatment [21,40]. The palladium species are encapsulated in the bulk and beyond the electron mean free path probed with XPS. As a result, surface palladium content detected by XPS is smaller obviouly. 3.5 CO adsorption The chemical states of palladium species in fresh and aged Pd/Ce/Al and Ce/Pd/Al catalysts were investigated by FT-IR measurements. FT-IR spectra of CO species adsorbed on the all catalysts heat-treated at 450 °C in H2 gas atmosphere are shown in Fig. 4 . For fresh catalysts, two kinds of IR bands (1960–1990, 2090 cm−1) are separately ascribed to bridged CO adsorbed to Pd0, linear CO on Pd0 [41,42]. For Pd/Al-f catalyst, the IR band intensity of linearly adsorbed CO is obviously weaker than that of bridged CO. This result indicates that palladium species in Pd/Al-f catalysts without Ce loading were worse dispersed. For Ce/Pd/Al-f and Pd/Ce/Al-f catalysts, the IR band intensity of linearly adsorbed CO was obviously stronger than that of bridged CO, which indicates that palladium species in Ce/Pd/Al-f and Pd/Ce/Al-f catalysts with Ce addition were highly dispersed and ceria can improve the dispersion of Pd species well, due to the interaction between PdO and cerium species [30]. Moreover, for Ce/Pd/Al-f, the fact that the IR band intensity of linearly adsorbed CO was relatively stronger than that of bridged CO is more obvious than Pd/Ce/Al-f catalyst. This result further implies that palladium species in the catalysts loaded Ce after Pd were dispersed better than the catalysts loaded Pd after Ce, which is due to the sintering of higher surface Pd concentration of the catalysts loaded Pd after Ce, which is sufficiently in accordance with the result probed with XPS. As is well known, CO adsorption can reflect the surface Pd dispersion of catalysts. After thermal treatment at 1000 °C, particles size became larger obviously and the palladium dispersion decreased significantly [43,44]. For Pd/Ce/Al-a, the IR band intensity of linearly adsorbed CO (2094 cm−1) was obviously weaker than that of bridged CO (1997 cm−1), which declares that palladium species in Pd/Ce/Al were worse dispersed after thermal treatment. However, for Ce/Pd/Al-a catalyst, the IR band intensity of linearly adsorbed CO (1967 cm−1) was obviously stronger than that of bridged CO (2090 cm−1), which shows that linearly adsorbed CO of catalyst loaded Ce after Pd is dominating and palladium species in Ce/Pd/Al-a catalysts were better dispersed on the support, indicating that the catalysts loaded Ce after Pd show more excellent thermal stability than the catalysts loaded Pd after Ce after aging treatment, which is in better accordance with XRD and XPS results. Aiming at above-mentioned result, it results from higher surface Pd content of Pd/Ce/Al verified by XPS, which facilitates Pd serious agglomerate during high temperature treatment and some part of palladium components seem not to play a role as active site [23], leading lower deispersion than Ce/Pd/Al-a catalyst and showing lower catalytic activity. Therefore, regardless of the fresh and aged catalysts, Ce/Pd/Al is in possession of larger palladium dispersion than Pd/Ce/Al, and exhibits more desirable catalytic activity. It is noteworthy that the shifts of wavenumber position for these bands are observed distinctly in Fig. 4. According to previous work reported [42,45,46], the shift in the peak position reflects the intensity of interaction that PdO particles undergo with support, suggesting that different loading sequences of CeO2 and Pd(NO3)2 can affect the interaction between PdO particles and support. Hence, the shifts of peak position declare that the different loading sequences have a great effect on the strong metal-support interaction (SMSI), showing different resistance to thermal deactivation during the thermal treatment, leading to different the dispersion of palladium species and with large Pd dispersion to clear superiority on catalytic performance. 3.6 TEM HRTEM images of aged catalysts are showed in Figs. 5 and 6 , respectively. For Pd/Ce/Al-a catalyst, as is shown in Fig. 5, PdO (110) plane [47] and CeO2 (220) plane are detected as inferred from the measured lattice spacing values, and alumina is almost amorphous. From Fig. 5(a), we see obviously that PdO particles are found in contact with the ceria, and do not obtain sufficient dispersion on the Al2O3, which is consistent with the result of the other literatures [12]. However, for Ce/Pd/Al-a catalyst, PdO (110), Pd (111) [48] and CeO2 (200) [39] planes are obtained respectively by HRTEM. From Fig. 6(a)–(c), PdO particles are well distributed and stabilized on the alumina and ceria, and CeO2 particles are dispersed on the alumina, suggesting that PdO particles still interact with ceria and alumina after aging thermal treatment by forming PdOCe bonds [21] and PdOAl bonds [49], respectively. Therefore, palladium species can keep higher dispersion by the interaction and the decreasing dispersion by sintering could strongly deteriorate the catalytic activity of supported Pd catalysts. From Figs. 5 (b) and 6 (b) and (d), the catalyst loaded Pd after Ce obviously possesses higher surface PdO content than the catalyst loaded Ce after Pd, which is in accordance with the result probed by XPS. PdO particles mean size of Pd/Ce/Al-a catalyst is about 5.64 nm, which is obviously larger than PdO particles size of Ce/Pd/Al-a catalyst whose particles mean size is about 5.28 nm calculated by TEM images. Meanwhile, as is showed in Fig. 7 , we can also obtain that the particles size of Ce/Pd/Al-a catalyst mainly focuses on 2–6 nm, while for Pd/Ce/Al-a catalyst the particles size mainly ranges from 4 to 8 nm, declaring that after aging treatment Ce/Pd/Al catalyst still keeps smaller PdO particles size and can distribute PdO particles well on the support, and it is possibility that PdO particles are stabilized on the ceria and alumina by forming strong interaction and ceria with palladium species can occupy the different space site over the alumina, leading to no direct contaction of palladium species (i.e. “diffusion barrier”), which can restrict the agglomeration of particles during the high temperature aging effectively [50]. It also explained that Ce/Pd/Al-a catalyst keeps stronger reducibility due to its smaller particles size versus Pd/Ce/Al-a catalyst [23]. As a result, Ce as second loading layer shows higher thermal stability and palladium dispersion, which verifies the result of CO adsorption again. Ciuparu et al. have reported that reduced Pd is more effective for NO decomposition than oxidized Pd in the interface of CeO2 [51]. Combining the TEM photographes with relative works, the active component palladium as second layer closely contacts with ceria, and its content of metal palladium is lower than the Pd catalyst that palladium component is loaded on the Al2O3, which is obtained by XPS. From many HRTEM images, we can see that for Pd/Ce/Al-a catalyst, PdO particles are mainly in contact with CeO2 and dispersed on CeO2, while for Ce/Pd/Al-a catalyst, PdO particles contact with CeO2 and Al2O3 and metal Pd is detected on the alumina. Therefore, Ce/Pd/Al-a catalyst owns higher palladium despersion than Pd/Ce/Al-a catalyst, which can promote the conversion of C3H8, NO and CO. As a result, Ce/Pd/Al-a catalyst shows higher catalytic activity, especially NO conversion. The reason why Ce/Pd/Al-a catalyst has a so great advantage for NO is that not only does it own higher palladium dispersion, but slso higher metal palladium content, which is active site of NO conversion [12]. The discrepancy obtained by XPS can be explained here. Both of the external surface oxygen vacancies are very close by calculating, while the gap of the catalytic activity is significantly obvious, demonstrating that the influencing the catalytic performance is not the surface oxygen vacancies but other factors, i.e. the dispersion of palladium species. To further get more information about the distribution of the different chemical elements at lower magnification, the EDS points-canning was carried out on the aged Pd/Ce/Al and Ce/Pd/Al samples (Fig. 8 ) and the results of elementals content are shown in Table 5. For the Pd/Ce/Al-a sample, the elemental content of Pd is 10.41 wt% in point a1 while no palladium exists in point c1. Meanwhile, for the Ce/Pd/Al-a catalyst, the elemental content of Pd is 9.46 wt% in point e1 whereas palladium species are not detected in point g1, suggesting that there are palladium species in the black areas, and white areas are mainly composed of non-noble metal species, which directly proves the above lattice fringe analysis detected by the HRTEM. Noticeable difference can be found among the four elements, and the precious metal distributions are obviously not homogeneous on the support surface, demonstrating that the palladium species have experienced the serious sintering after the thermal treatment, which can explain why palladium species are not detected in point c1 and g1. 3.7 In situ DRIFTS results Detailed DRIFTS were carried out over the fresh and aged catalysts. Time-course spectra for the catalysts in the range of 2500 cm−1 to 500 cm−1 are shown in Fig. 9 . For Pd/Ce/Al-f (Fig. 9(a)), the adsorption peaks at 1540 cm−1 and 1390 cm−1 are observed, which are assigned to the vibration of carbonate, suggesting that surface ceria of Pd/Ce/Al-f easily reacts with CO and the generation of carbonate. In comparison, the two peaks concerning the vibration of carbonate over Ce/Pd/Al-f (Fig. 9(b)) are not evident, which reveals that surface ceria of Ce/Pd/Al-f reacts with CO difficultly or surface carbon dioxide generated possesses stronger desorption property and seems to be adverse to forming carbonate. However, the peaks around 2097 cm−1 and 1976 cm−1 associating with the linear (Pd0-CO) and bridged carbonyls (Pd0-CO-Pd0), are found, indicating that Pd0 contacts with CO at 50 °C or lower immediately. After aging treatment, more Pd0 species existed over the surface of the catalysts and the on-top adsorption of CO was found on both of the aged catalysts, which is benefit to the conversion of CO at room temperature. However, the fact that desorption of CO2 is harder than the corresponding fresh one declares that the coverage of the active sites is severer. The band at 1598 cm−1 ascribed to acetate is obviously detected at 150 °C for Ce/Pd/Al-f and 170 °C for Pd/Ce/Al-f. Acetate is an intermediate product during C3H8 oxidation, suggesting that part of the C3H8 starts to convert, and the conversion of C3H8 over Ce/Pd/Al-f is at relatively lower temperature, which declares that catalytic activity of Ce/Pd/Al-f for the conversion of C3H8 is better than that of Pd/Ce/Al-f. It is noteworthy that the onset conversion temperature of C3H8 is above 250 °C, higher than that of revealed in DRIFTS, a possible explanation is that the existence of competitive adsorption of water vapor and C3H8 in the activity test process whereas no water vapor existed in the gas mixture of DRIFTS. After aging treatment, the formation temperature of acetate over the two aged catalysts is not observed, and this may result from unfitted temperature interval. The formation of isocyanate is crucially labeled as NO reduction, as we can see in Fig. 9(a and b), and there is a distinct difference between the two fresh samples. For Pd/Ce/Al-f, bands ascribed to isocyanate chemisorbed at Pd0 and Al3+ (at ∼2143 cm−1 and 2228 cm−1) appeared, suggesting that the NO + CO reaction starts to take place [52,53]. In addition, the presence of Pd0-NCO also revealed the decomposition of PdO x . Comparatively speaking, no significant peak concerning Pd0-NCO is detected over Ce/Pd/Al-f, and the intensity of 2228 cm−1 is very weak. There might be three reasons for this phenomenon. Firstly, ceria is covered over the surface of Pd, thus Pd species which are exposed to the surface are limited, leading to the absence of Pd0-NCO adsorption peak. Secondly, just as H2-TPR revealed, PdO x species are more stable and the reduction temperature was higher over Ce/Pd/Al-f, which could also result in the nonexistence of Pd0-NCO. Thirdly, it is assumed that surface oxygen over CeO2 would accelerate the reduction of NO. The NO conversion performance over Ce/Pd/Al-f is preferable and the content of ceria on the surface of Ce/Pd/Al-f is higher than that of Pd/Ce/Al-f, thus it is reasonable that the weak signal of Al3+-NCO is due to the fast reduction of NO. For aged catalysts, the adsorption of isocyanate over Al3+ is much lower than that of fresh ones, indicating that the aging treatment may causes a sintering of the active sites. In addition, it’s remarkable that a band at ∼1888 cm−1 [54] was observed when reaction temperature elevated to 330 °C for Pd/Ce/Al-f and 350 °C for Ce/Pd/Al-f, and the peak is more significant over the former catalyst. 3.8 Schematic diagram of Pd dispersion According to the characterization results mentioned above, especially CO adsorption and HRTEM, brief mode of palladium dispersion on the Al2O3 support at different impregnation sequence is shown in Fig. 10 . For the Ce/Pd/Al catalysts, firstly ca. 1.5 wt% Pd2+ (theoretical value: 1.64 wt%) is loaded on the Al2O3 support, and then Ce is supported. Pd2+ is dispersed on the Al2O3, and their interaction is formed by Al-O-Pd bonds which are weaker than CeOPd bonds obviously [30]. The addition of ceria in the nanometer scale separates palladium particles in space, which acts as a diffusion barrier [15]. As a result, the direct contact of palladium particles is restricted due to the addition of ceria by forming strong interaction of CeOPd bonds [21] and growth of the particles can be inhibited during the aging treatment, which could minish the decrease of palldium dispersion and palladium size siginificantly. Therefore, for the Ce/Pd/Al catalysts, more active sites play a significant role on catalytic performance. However, for the Pd/Ce/Al catalysts, firstly 17.5 wt% Ce is loaded on the Al2O3 support, and then Pd2+ is loaded by consecutive wetness impregnation method. Al2O3 and cerium are Lewis acid and base, respectively, and their interaction is stronger than that between palladium species and alumina distinctly [30] and the content of cerium is relatively more, which can render cerium that can be dispersed on the Al2O3 support surface closely. The addition of palladium particles is stabilized on the surface of cerium, and the surface palladium concentration is higher than the catalysts loaded Ce after Pd apparently in accordance with XPS result, while the contact of palladium particles isn’t restricted effectively and directly. As a result, the growth of the particles cannot be inhibited effectively during the aging treatment, which decreases palladium dispersion to some extent. Hence, as HRTEM shows, we can see that PdO particles are fixed on the ceria. 3.9 Catalytic performances Fig. 11 depicts the conversion curve of C3H8, NO and CO for fresh and aged catalysts. The corresponding light-off temperature (T 50) and full conversion temperature (T 90) were summarized in Table 6 . For fresh catalysts (Fig. 11a, c and e), Ce/Pd/Al-f displays a superior catalytic activity for C3H8, NO and CO eliminations compared with Pd/Ce/Al-f, and the light-off temperatures for all target pollutants over Ce/Pd/Al-f are obviously lower than that of Pd/Ce/Al-f. After aging treatment (presented in Fig. 11b, d and f), a notable decline of catalytic activity was observed in both of two aged catalysts. The T 50 for all target pollutants increases almost for 40 °C in comparison with the corresponding fresh one, and this phenomenon is familiar with literature reported before. The possible reason might correlate to the deterioration of support structure and sintering of active components [44,55]. It is generally thought that the coexistence of Ce3+ and Ce4+ is an indication of oxygen vacancies, which is of prime importance to the redox properties and the corresponding close coupled catalystic activity. It is noteworthy that the onset conversion temperature of C3H8 is above 250 °C, much higher than that of revealed in DRIFTS, and a possible explanation is that the existence of competitive adsorption of water vapor and C3H8 in the activity test process whereas no water vapor existed in the gas mixture of DRIFTS. For the fresh catalysts, Ce/Pd/Al-f pocesses relatively lower lattice constants and forms more oxygen vacancies related to the Ce3+ species in the lattice [40]. For Pd supported catalysts, the oxygen vacancies related to the Ce3+ species close to the noble metal particles are proposed to be active sites for NO activation, so the higher proportion of Ce3+ can facilitate NO catalytic activity [56]. In other words, Ce/Pd/Al-f owns more oxygen vacancies which can contribute to the catalytic activity, whereas both of oxygen vacancies are extraordinarily close, suggesting that oxygen vacancies are excluded from influencing the catalytic performance. From the above discussion, we can know that Ce/Pd/Al-f catalyst is in possession of lower surface PdO content probed by XPS and presents the larger dispersion of palladium species acquired by CO adsorption. Meanwhile, Ce/Pd/Al-f catalyst possesses larger surface area and smaller CeO2 partice size obtained by BET and XRD results, and the interaction between ceria and palladium species facilitates the dispersion of PdOX on the support surface by forming the PdOCe bonds [21]. Therefore, Ce/Pd/Al-f shows superior catalytic activity than Pd/Ce/Al-f due to its better palladium dispersion. For the aged catalysts, Ce/Pd/Al-a displays a superior catalytic activity for C3H8, NO and CO eliminations than Pd/Ce/Al-a, especially NO conversion. However, the catalyst loaded Ce after Pd owns lower Pd2+, Ce3+ and surface palladium species content after the aging treatment verified by XPS, which are considered as the active site of C3H8, NO and CO, while it shows more excellent catalytic activity for C3H8, NO and CO, whose activity result is the same as that of fresh catalysts. Underlying reasons may be responsible to explain this phenomenon: (i) As is well known, the redox property of the catalyst is crucial to its catalytic performance, and the excellent low temperature reduction ability of Ce/Pd/Al-a contributes well to its conversions of C3H8 and CO tested by H2-TPR. From the H2-TPR result, we can conclude that reduction temperature at 93 °C of Ce/Pd/Al-a assigned to PdO reduction peak is slightly lower than that of Pd/Ce/Al-a, but the reduction temperatre at 115 °C of Ce/Pd/Al-a is assigned to ceria reduction peak which is obviously lower than that of Pd/Ce/Al-a, declaring that Ce/Pd/Al-a can release oxygen atom at lower temperature and excel at the oxidation activity for C3H8 and CO. (ii) It is clarified that the oxidation activity for C3H8 and CO strongly relies on the finely dispersed PdO species and Ce/Pd/Al-a catalyst possesses smaller palladium particle size and ceria crystal than Pd/Ce/Al-a mentioned by TEM and XRD characterization, leading to higher Pd dispersion on the support surface, which is in better accordance with the result measured by CO adsorption method. As a result, more palladium oxide particles seem to play a role as active site. (iii) As we can see in Fig. 10 and Table 5, Ce/Pd/Al-a possesses better catalytic performance than that of Pd/Ce/Al-a, especially for NO conversion. It’s possibility that Ce/Pd/Al-a holds higher despersion and higher metal palladium content obtained by XPS due to palladium component contacting with the alumina, regardless of the fresh and aging catalysts, and more metal palladium sites play an active site of NO conversion [12]. With both of two factors, Ce/Pd/Al catalyst shows more excellent catalytic property for NO conversion. In sunmary, the catalytic activity of the fresh and the aged catalysts is strongly dependent on the palladium dispersion while the reduction property by H2-TPR is not main factor in influencing the catalytic performance. It can explain that Ce/Pd/Al-f catalyst shows more excellent catalytic activity, but it possesses lower reduction property. For the fresh catalysts, other factors such as textural and structure properties seem to facilitate the catalytic performance. However, for the aged catalysts, the catalytic performance is also subject to reduction property and surface metal palladium content, especially for NO conversion, and the T 50 of NO over Ce/Pd/Al-a is 27 °C lower than that of Pd/Ce/Al-a. The above results demonstrate that covering ceria over Pd and Al2O3 is beneficial to promote the catalytic activity and the promoted effect is maintained even after aging treatment. Fig. 12 depicts the light-off temperatures and full-conversion temperatures of C3H8, NO and CO for the aged Pd/Ce/Al, Ce/Pd/Al and Pd/CZ/Al close coupled catalysts. The Pd/CZ/Al catalyst is prepared by the same traditional stepwise impregnation method as the preparation of Pd/Ce/Al catalyst, while differently the former promoter is ceria-zircinia solution solid and ceria as additive is adopted by the latter. According to the expriments known, when the mass ratio of CZ (the molar ratio, 4:1) and Al2O3 is 3:7, the catalyst performs the most prominent catalytic activity. It can be seen in Fig. 12(a) that for Pd/CZ/Al-a catalyst, the light-off temperature of C3H8, NO and CO is 326 °C, 208 °C and 181 °C, respectively, while the value of the full-conversion temperature is 350 °C, 244 °C and 200 °C, respectively. With regard to the aged catalysts, greater distinction can be observed between the Pd/Ce/Al-a and Pd/CZ/Al-a catalysts. The Pd/CZ/Al-a catalyst presents more favorable catalytic activity than the Pd/Ce/Al-a catalyst, regardless of C3H8, NO and CO conversion, which is consistent with the literatures [19,57]. However, the Ce/Pd/Al catalyst performs almost the same catalytic performance as the Pd/CZ/Al catalyst, suggesting that the novel loading sequence can improve the catalytic activity and show higher thermal stability with Pd/CZ/Al catalyst before and after thermal deactivation. We reasonably assume that ceria-zirconia solid solution as promoter is adopted, and the catalyst prepared by novel loading sequence will present more remarkable catalytic performance which is promoted in the larger space. The latest literatures about the close coupled catalyst [16,58,59], have reported that for the best aged catalytic activity, T50 and T90 of C3H8 conversion are 320 °C and 351 °C, respectively, T50 and T90 are 226 °C and 250 °C for NO conversion, and 185 °C and 211 °C are ascribed to T50 and T90 of CO conversion. These values are distinctly higher than those of Ce/Pd/Al-a catalyst in this study, suggesting that Ce/Pd/Al-a catalyst exhibits significantly improved catalytic activity and breaks the record of close couple catalyst. In conclusion, the loading sequence makes a great progress in close coupled catalytic activity compared with the previous reported results. 4 Conclusions In this study, the effect of the different loading sequence of CeO2 and Pd over Al2O3 on the catalytic performance of Pd-only close-coupled catalysts is compared and the catalysts obtained by consecutive incipient wetness impregnation method show different catalytic performances obviously. The following conclusons can be obtained according to Section 3 mentioned above: The catalysts loaded Ce after Pd present higher catalytic activity of the elimination of NO, CO and C3H8 than the catalysts loaded Pd after Ce, especially NO conversion, irrespctively of the fresh and the aging catalysts. Ce/Pd/Al catalysts show superior structural properties before and after aging treatment at 1000 °C, suggesting that the catalysts loaded Ce after Pd manifest better thermal resistance and stability with the interaction due to CeOPd bonds [21,51], PdOAl bonds [49] and CeOAl bonds [60], leading to the results that Ce/Pd/Al catalysts possess higher palladium dispersion than Pd/Ce/Al catalysts on the support surface verified by CO adsorption method and HRTEM images, as is showed in schematic diagram. As a result, more palladium species of the catalysts loaded Ce after Pd seems to play a role as acive site, which promotes low temperature conversion of C3H8 and CO better. Meanwhile, the Ce/Pd/Al catalyst possesses higher metal palladium content, which can also facilitate catalytic activity of NO conversion to a large extent. coredata.dc:description: The Pd-only close-coupled catalysts of the different loading sequence of CeO2 and Pd over Al2O3 were prepared using consecutive wetness impregnation method. Differences in structural, surface properties and catalytic performance, together with the thermal aging behaviors of catalyst at 1000 °C were investigated systematically by XRD, TPR, XPS, ICP, CO adsorption and TEM. Consequently, the Ce/Pd/Al catalysts loaded Ce after Pd over the alumina show superior structural properties before and after aging treatment, suggesting the Ce/Pd/Al catalysts possess better thermal resistance than Pd/Ce/Al catalysts loaded Pd after Ce. Moreover, the aged Ce/Pd/Al catalysts possess stronger reducible probed by TPR, and HRTEM and CO adsorption show smaller particles size of Pd and higher palladium dispersion. As a result, for Ce/Pd/Al catalysts, more palladium sites play a role as active site, which promotes low temperature conversion of pollutants effectively. The catalytic performance of the catalysts is forcefully subject to palladium dispersion and reduction property, especially for NO conversion, and the light-off temperature of NO over aged Ce/Pd/Al is 27 °C lower than aged Pd/Ce/Al. The results have demonstrated that novel loading sequence is beneficial to catalytic activity which is maintained even after aging treatment.
coredata.dc:title: Effect of the loading sequence of CeO2 and Pd over Al2O3 on the catalytic performance of Pd-only close-coupled catalysts
